text: Lithium-ion batteries power our favorite electronics,
but they’re not great at handling stress.
Commercial lithium-ion batteries contain highly flammable organic compounds, which is why

they can turn into fireballs when they’re
stabbed, smashed, or overheated.
But scientists are working to change that.
We visited a team of researchers that have made a safer lithium-ion battery--one that
can withstand direct hits--by switching out organic compounds for water.
Kang: No matter how much you abuse the battery mechanically, they don’t catch fire, they don’t
result in a catastrophic ending.
Xu collaborated with researchers at the University of Maryland to design these safer batteries,
which can reach up to 4 volts. That’s the same voltage as lithium-ion batteries on the market
today.

And this is the first time an aqueous battery
has reached that level.

In the past, battery researchers have struggled
to reach this level with aqueous electrolytes.

Above modest voltages, battery electrodes
react with water, forming hydrogen and oxygen,

and also
decomposing the electrodes.

The team overcame this problem by coating
a battery’s anode with a special fluorinated
polymer.

This hydrophobic layer protects the anode
to keep it from reacting with water.

And the coating is compatible with current
battery materials.

Chunsheng: Then we can use anything that is suitable for current
organic electrode anode and cathode, we can

use it, just replace the electrolyte and put
an additional coating; that is the advantage
of our technology.

University of Maryland postdoc Chongyin Yang
showed us how he makes these aqueous batteries.

Step one, make the anode by combining powdered
graphite with a small amount of binder, which
helps to form a spreadable mud-like slurry.

Step two, evenly spread the slurry onto a
copper film.

This graphite-coated copper serves as a battery’s
anode.
Step three, dry the anode in a very hot oven.

Step four, coat the anode with a thin layer
of protective fluorinated polymer.
Normally he would do this in a glove box, but he's showing us on the bench where it's easier to see.

Finally, put the anode inside a small button
battery, add the aqueous electrolyte, cap
it off with a cathode, and press down hard.
Then you’re basically done.

Chongyin: So right now it’s a cell, a battery,
we can test it.

One side is the anode side and one side is the
cathode side.
Nguyen: So that’s a working battery now?
Chongyin: Yea, uh no, we need to charge it first.

The team is collaborating with two battery
manufacturers, Saft and Liox, to take their

coating technology from the lab into commercial
batteries, but there’s still some work to

do. The batteries can be recharged
70 times, but they want to increase that number

to 500, which is the benchmark for commercial
batteries.

Kisuk Kang, a materials expert at Seoul National
University who wasn’t involved in the study,

says that the researchers still need to increase
the battery’s coulombic efficiency, which

is essentially the charge you put into a battery
versus the charge you get out.

The aqueous battery’s efficiency is between
98-99.5%.

Lithium ion batteries on the market today
reach efficiencies of greater than 99.9%.

Still, Kang calls the work a “significant
breakthrough.”

And Xu and Wang say their team plans to screen
more electrode coating materials to improve
the batteries’ properties.
